title: Understanding Our Soil: The Nitrogen Cycle Fixers and Fertilizer

tasks.task: Understanding the role of nitrogen-fixing plants in agriculture.
subtasks: Recognize that peas, beans, and clover are nitrogen-fixing plants.
Identify the benefits of nitrogen fixation for soil fertility.
Understand the process of how nitrogen-fixing plants support the broader nitrogen cycle.
Compare the impact of nitrogen fixers versus synthetic fertilizers on soil and ecosystem health.
Appreciate the importance of maintaining soil fertility through natural means.

tasks.task: Interplanting nitrogen-fixing plants with other crops.
subtasks: Learn when to interplant nitrogen fixers with high-nitrogen-demanding plants.
Consider usingcover crops like clover to prepare soil for future plantings.
Understand how nitrogen-fixing plants contribute to long-term soil fertility (e.g., forming nodules with bacteria).
Recognize the residual benefits of dead nitrogen-fixing plants for soil health.

tasks.task: Analyzing the impacts of synthetic nitrogen fertilizers on soil and environment.
subtasks: Observe the drawbacks of synthetic fertilizers in terms of soil health and water pollution.
Understand the processes leading to water pollution from synthetic fertilizers (runoff, volatilization).
Grasp the consequences of synthetic fertilizers on soil biology (damage to earthworms, fungi, pH alteration).
Relate the depletion of soil organisms to the increased need for further fertilization and its cyclical effects.

tasks.task: Linking soil health to nutritional value of crops.
subtasks: Understand the historical trend of decreasing vegetable nutritional value due to poor soil.
Connect the concept of healthy soil to nutrient-rich produce.
Reflect on the importance of sustainable soil management practices (like nitrogen fixers) for future food quality.

tasks.task: Conserving soil organisms through natural farming methods.
subtasks: Recognize the role of fungi in nutrient transport to plants.
Consider the importance of maintaining ecosystems underfoot for overall soil health.
Understand the balance between added nutrients and nurturing natural soil processes.

tasks.task: Understanding the nitrogen cycle and its importance to agriculture.
Recognize and explain the process of nitrogen fixation in legumes.
subtasks: Identify legumes that fix nitrogen (peas, beans, clover).
Explain how nodules on legume roots harbor nitrogen-fixing bacteria.
Describe the release of ammonium into the soil by these bacteria.

tasks.task: Interplanting nitrogen-fixing legumes with other crops.
subtasks: Choose appropriate crops to interplant with nitrogen fixers (high nitrogen需求的作物).
Determine the right time to interplant nitrogen-fixing plants (may be with the primary crop's growing cycle).
Plant nitrogen-fixing plants among existing crops.

tasks.task: Interplant a cover crop of clover in a cornfield.
subtasks: Plan when to plant the cover crop for maximum benefits.
Prepare the soil by tilling or aerating.
Sow clover seeds evenly among the corn rows.
Monitor the growth of clover and corn together.

tasks.task: Plant beans in an orchard as a nitrogen-fixing crop.
subtasks: Choose a nitrogen-fixing bean variety suitable for orchard crops.
Prepare the planting area, ensuring proper spacing and nutrients.
Direct-seed the beans in between the orchard rows.
Water and mulch the area to support young plants.

tasks.task: Create a nitrogen-fixing mound.
subtasks: Mix compost or potting soil with organic matter.
Plant nitrogen-fixing clover in the mound.

tasks.task: Interplant clover with corn.
subtasks: Calculate the number of corn rows to plant between.
Sow clover seeds at the appropriate depth and spacing between corn plants.
Ensure proper light and water conditions for both corn and clover.

tasks.task: Planting a clover cover crop in a vegetable garden.
subtasks: Till or cultivate the garden soil.
Prepare seedbed by smoothing the soil.
Broadcast clover seeds evenly over the surface.
Cover seeds lightly with soil and tamp them down.
Water the planting area thoroughly.

tasks.task: Plant legume cover crops.
subtasks: Dig or till soil to prepare planting area.
Sow legume seeds at appropriate depth and spacing.
Water new crop and mulch to conserve moisture.

tasks.task: Build a structure that supports a legume-laden greenhouse.
subtasks: Assemble frames or trellises for vines like peas or beans.
Cover frames with appropriate mesh or netting.
Plant legume seeds around the structure.

tasks.task: Research and develop a plan to introduce nitrogen-fixing plants into existing farmland.
subtasks: Identify suitable legume species for local conditions.
Calculate the number of grams or pounds of seeds needed.
Choose a cover crop planting technique (sowing, broadcasting, broadcasting and covering, etc.).
Schedule planting according to the crop rotation calendar.

tasks.task: Plant a clover cover crop in a garden plot.
subtasks: Weed the plot to remove existing vegetation.
Till the soil to a depth of about 4 inches.
Mix in compost or organic matter.
Broadcast clover seeds over the soil and rake them in slightly.
Water the area thoroughly.

tasks.task: Interplant beans with a summer vegetable.
subtasks: Mark rows where beans will be planted.
Sow bean seeds every 6 inches along rows.
Plant the companion vegetable at the same time, spacing as per their needs.
Mulch around the plants to retain moisture.

tasks.task: Establish a legume-based living mulch system.
subtasks: Choose a legume that also acts as a mulch (like clover).
Plant legume seeds around the perimeter of fields or between rows.
Mulch paths or areas between the living plants.
Manage weeds by mowing or hand weeding between the legumes.
